awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Probing Attosecond Charge Dynamics in Atoms and Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
An ability to identify, tag and follow unambiguously quantum trajectories of electrons in molecular systems is central to addressing questions that are key to unlocking solutions to an array of contemporary scientific and technical challenges - understanding the chemistry of interstellar media, reducing our carbon footprint, enabling efficient, clean energy sources and controlling dynamics in biological molecules are just a few examples.  Light-induced charge dynamics, for example, is ubiquitous in catalysis, photosynthesis, the photovoltaic effect, radiation damage in biomolecules and atmospheric chemistry. With clock speeds of order 1 femtosecond (10^-15 s), the energy flow and correlated dance between electrons and atomic nuclei require subfemtosecond temporal resolution (e.g., 100 attosecond = 0.1 femtosecond) and carefully-designed experimental techniques to track reliably.  The University of Central Florida (UCF) - University of Maryland (UMD) collaboration has assembled the instrumentation and personnel to study such dynamics in important prototype molecules.  Specifically, charge dynamics will be probed experimentally by transient changes in the absorption spectrum of so-called core-level states (those closest to the nucleus) of the carbon atom. These novel measurements may lead to new understanding of key physical concepts, clearer pictures of fundamental processes and novel ways to control electron dynamics.   

Employing a few-cycle infrared intense (IR) pump and an attosecond soft X-ray probe in the water window (240 to 330 eV in this study) for transient absorption of core-level carbon atoms, the University of Central Florida (UCF) - University of Maryland (UMD) collaboration is investigating ultrafast dynamics in two important hydrocarbons.  One set of experiments is dedicated to tracking structural changes induced by the IR pulse in methane as it loses hydrogen atoms (deprotonization) with subfemtosecond temporal resolution. The second study focuses on IR-induced isomerization of acetylene into vinilydene also with subfemtosecond resolution.  One novelty of these studies rests in a forty-fold improvement in temporal resolution over previous transient absorption measurements in the water window.  The UCF-UMD collaboration is ideally suited to carry out this investigation because of the investigators' long history in building and operating state-of-the-art attosecond lasers (UCF) and probing and controlling atomic and molecular dynamics (UMD).  To ensure the best interpretation of the experimental results, the team works closely with UCF theorists running contemporary numerical codes such as XCHEM and MESA to help analyze the data.  The results will provide new insight into time-dependent structure changes and correlated electron motion induced by strong external perturbation, which potentially could reveal innovative ways to control electron dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
X-rays are short wavelength electromagnetic waves, which can also be considered as particles called photons.  Extreme short X-ray bursts can be produced by interacting noble gas atoms with intense laser pulses. In the past, attosecond X-ray sources with less than 200-eV photon energy have been developed, which were driven by near infrared lasers.  In this program, a few-cycle short-wave infrared (SWIR) laser pulse and an attosecond soft X-ray burst with 250 to 400 eV photon energy were used to initiate and monitor ultrafast electron dynamics in atoms and molecules. Electrons in an atom are arranged in shells around the nucleus. The shell closest to the core of the atom is named the K-shell. The electrons in the outermost shell are called valence electrons. When the energy of an X-ray photon matches the binding energy difference between an inner shell and a valence shell of an atom, it can be strongly absorbed by an electron. In one set of experiments, it was demonstrated, for the first time, that the fast motion of L-shell electrons induced by an X-ray pulse with 250-eV photon energy in argon atoms could be monitored by a photoelectron spectroscopy technique named streaking. In the second study, it was shown that intense SWIR laser-induced dynamics of valence electrons in nitrogen oxide and nitrous oxide molecules could be observed at the nitrogen K-edge (400 eV) by attosecond transient absorption spectroscopy. The temporal resolution for both sets of experiments was subfemtosecond resolution, which are unprecedented in time-resolved spectroscopy experiments at the 250 to 400 eV photon energy range.

The demonstrations of attosecond photoelectron and absorption spectroscopy pave the way to study many important ultrafast processes in physics and chemistry such as charge migration, charge trasnfer and interatomic Coulomb decay in organic and other molecules. The program supported two graduate students, two undergraduate students and one postdoctoral fellow to work in one of the most exciting forefronts of atomic, molecular and optical physics, while trained them to become leaders in the research area of ultrafast molecular dynamics and experts in attosecond technologies. Two courses on attosecond optics and physics were offered at the University of Central Florida for undergraduate and graduate students, with lab demonstrations held in the attosecond facility supported by this program.
